about.title: About Ahmet Özay
about.intro: Journalist | Publisher | Media Expert | Member of the Crimean Tatar National Assembly
about.paragraph1: Ahmet Özay (born November 1, 1961, in Üsküdar, Istanbul) is a German-Turkish journalist, publisher, and media expert. After graduating in Social and Cultural Anthropology from Istanbul Üniversitesi, he completed his doctorate at the Institute of Ethnology at the University of Cologne. He also received journalistic training at Westdeutscher Rundfunk (WDR) in Cologne.
about.paragraph2: His journalistic career, which began in the early 1990s, led him to executive positions and as a correspondent for numerous international media organizations. Özay worked as a Europe correspondent and editor-in-chief at Sabah, ATV, Show TV, Sky Türk, TRT Türk, and the Kırım Haber Ajansı in Kiev, where he most recently served as general director. He has also worked for renowned broadcasters such as BBC World, Deutsche Welle, WDR, and Netherlands World Service.
about.paragraph3: Today, Ahmet Özay is active as a publisher and media commentator, writes regularly for Turkish and European media, and provides expert commentary in television programs on political and social issues. His expertise includes German-Turkish relations, the Crimean Tatar diaspora, and developments in Russia, Ukraine, and Crimea.
about.paragraph4: For over twenty years, Özay has been actively involved in the Kırım Tatar Milli Meclisi and serves as a leading voice of the Crimean Turkish community as the representative of the Kırım Tatar Milli Meclisi in Germany. With his wealth of experience and intercultural understanding, he embodies a comprehensive journalistic approach that bridges political and cultural perspectives between Europe, Turkey, and the post-Soviet space.

krimtataren.title: Crimean Tatars Expert | Ahmet Özay
krimtataren.description: Ahmet Özay - German Crimean Tatars expert and member of the Crimean Tatar People's Mejlis. Expert on Crimea politics, Crimea analysis and the history of Crimean Tatars.
krimtataren.intro: Ahmet Özay is one of Germany's leading experts on Crimean Tatars and Crimea politics. As a member of the Crimean Tatar People's Mejlis and a veteran journalist with 40+ years of experience at WDR, BBC and Deutsche Welle, he provides in-depth analysis on the situation of Crimean Tatars, the Crimea annexation and geopolitical developments in the region.
content: The Crimean Tatars are a Turkic-speaking minority on the Crimean Peninsula who have experienced a complex and often tragic history. From the deportation in 1944 by Stalin to the annexation of Crimea by Russia in 2014, the Crimean Tatars have always fought for their rights and their homeland.

Ahmet Özay, himself of Crimean Tatar origin, has established himself as one of the leading experts on Crimean Tatars in Germany. His work focuses on analyzing the political, social and cultural developments of the Crimean Tatar community, both in Ukraine and in the diaspora.

As a member of the Crimean Tatar People's Mejlis and Germany representative, Ahmet Özay actively advocates for the rights of Crimean Tatars and informs the German public about the current situation in Crimea.

expertise.description: In-depth analysis of the 2014 Crimea annexation, the geopolitical significance of the Crimean Peninsula and international responses to the Russian occupation.

expertise.description: Comprehensive knowledge of Crimean Tatar history, from the 1944 deportation to the current situation, as well as the cultural identity and traditions of the community.

expertise.title: Minority Rights & Human Rights
expertise.description: Expertise in minority rights, human rights and the legal situation of Crimean Tatars under Russian occupation.

expertise.title: Diaspora & Integration
expertise.description: Knowledge of the Crimean Tatar diaspora in Germany, Turkey and other countries, as well as issues of integration and cultural identity.

krimtatarenFaq.title: Frequently Asked Questions about Crimean Tatars

items.question: Who are the Crimean Tatars?
items.answer: The Crimean Tatars are a Turkic-speaking minority on the Crimean Peninsula. They are the original inhabitants of Crimea and have a complex history ranging from the deportation by Stalin in 1944 to the current situation under Russian occupation. The Crimean Tatars are Sunni Muslims and have a rich cultural tradition.

items.question: What is the Crimean Tatar People's Mejlis?
items.answer: The Crimean Tatar People's Mejlis (Kırım Tatar Milli Meclisi) is the representative assembly of Crimean Tatars. It was founded in 1991 and represents the interests of Crimean Tatars both in Crimea and in the diaspora. Ahmet Özay is a member of the Mejlis and serves as the Germany representative.

items.question: What happened during the 2014 Crimea annexation?
items.answer: In March 2014, Russia annexed the Crimean Peninsula, which was internationally condemned as illegal. The annexation led to a deterioration of the human rights situation for Crimean Tatars, who have been living under Russian occupation since then. Many Crimean Tatars were persecuted, their rights restricted and their cultural institutions closed.

items.question: What is the current situation of Crimean Tatars?
items.answer: Crimean Tatars have been living under Russian occupation since 2014 and face numerous challenges: persecution, restriction of their rights, closure of cultural institutions and suppression of their language and culture. Many Crimean Tatars have fled to Ukraine or abroad. The international community has not recognized the annexation.

items.question: Why is Ahmet Özay an expert on Crimean Tatars?
items.answer: Ahmet Özay is himself of Crimean Tatar origin and a member of the Crimean Tatar People's Mejlis. With over 40 years of experience as a journalist at renowned media outlets such as WDR, BBC and Deutsche Welle, he has established himself as one of Germany's leading experts on Crimean Tatars. He regularly analyzes the political, social and cultural developments of the Crimean Tatar community.

items.question: Is there a Crimean Tatar diaspora in Germany?
items.answer: Yes, there is an active Crimean Tatar community in Germany that advocates for the rights of their compatriots in Crimea. Ahmet Özay, as the Germany representative of the Crimean Tatar People's Mejlis, is an important voice for this community and informs the German public about the situation of Crimean Tatars.
